description: From French fibre, from Old French, from Latin fibra.

nouns.description: fibre (countable and uncountable, plural fibres) (Britain, Canada, Australia, Ireland, New Zealand, South Africa spellings)

entries.meaning: (countable) A single piece of a given material, elongated and roughly round in cross-section, often twisted with other fibres to form thread.
examples: The microscope showed several different fibres stuck to the sole of the shoe.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Material in the form of fibres.
examples: The cloth was made from strange, somewhat rough fibre.
Fresh vegetables are a good source of fibre.
The ordeal was a test of everyone’s fibre.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) The preimage of a given point in the range of a map.
examples: Under this map, any two values in the fibre of a given point on the circle differ by 2π

entries.meaning: (category theory) Said to be of a morphism over a global element: The pullback of the said morphism along the said global element.
(computing) A kind of lightweight thread of execution.
(cytology) A long tubular cell found in bodily tissue.
examples: Hyponyms: axon, myocyte, muscle fibre, nerve fibre
